key_points: Congress did not approve a $2,000 stimulus check as part of the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021.
President Joe Biden, Senator Chuck Schumer, and Senator Bernie Sanders were among those who touted $2,000 stimulus payments before and after the Senate runoff elections in Georgia.
The American Rescue Plan includes $1,400 stimulus checks for individuals and $2,800 for married and joint filers, not the $2,000 initially suggested.
Some Democrats, including Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Rep. Cori Bush, highlighted the discrepancy between the promised $2,000 and the delivered $1,400 checks.
There were proposals for providing $2,000 stimulus checks on a monthly basis until the end of the Covid-19 pandemic.
Criticisms were raised against President Biden for not delivering on the full $2,000 stimulus check as promised.
The Biden administration argued that the combination of the second stimulus check of $600 and the third of $1,400 equals $2,000 in total stimulus payments.
Biden was mentioned as being preferential towards a stimulus package that could realistically be passed, acknowledging the hesitance of moderate Democrats regarding a $2,000 check.
A family of four could receive a total of $5,600 in stimulus payments from the third stimulus check, under the conditions laid out in the legislation.
The article presents an examination of the promises versus the reality of the stimulus checks, leaving it to readers to decide if the "promise" was kept.
